meaning_mnemonic:
Noun version of <kanji>decide</kanji>? It's a <vocabulary>decision</vocabulary>.

決 is a formal word that refers to a decisive <vocabulary>verdict</vocabulary>. It's used in formal phrases like 決を採る (to take a vote) or 決を下す (to pass a judgment), both of which are about making decisions or delivering verdicts.

Something that is <kanji>not yet</kanji> <kanji>decide</kanji>d... it is <vocabulary>pending</vocabulary>!

未決 is a formal term, typically used in legal or administrative contexts to refer to matters that are still <vocabulary>unresolved</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>undecided</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>particle</kanji> (粒子) that is the <kanji>element</kanji> version of it is an <vocabulary>elementary particle</vocabulary>.

握り is a "grip." When you add お it's elevated a bit. For some reason it becomes a <vocabulary>rice ball</vocabulary> (aka <vocabulary>onigiri</vocabulary>). To make a rice ball, you use your grip to make them into a ball shape, which is probably where it comes from.

Remember how 揚げる can mean "to deep fry"? 揚げ出し is a Japanese cooking technique where you deep fry something (usually tofu) and serve it in broth. This word might be easy to remember if you know that "dashi" soup stock is often used to make the agedashi broth.
叫ぶ is "to shout" and "to scream." This is the noun version. This is a <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scream</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>shout</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>yell</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>sprout</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sprout</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bud</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shoot</vocabulary>. All sprouts are new, after all.
Remember 焦る, which means "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient"? This is the noun version, which is <vocabulary>impatience</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

An <kanji>ink</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ink painting</vocabulary>.

墨絵 refers to artwork created in monochrome, using black sumi ink with a brush on handmade paper.
If you <kanji>enter</kanji> <kanji>ink</kanji> into (your body), you are getting yourself a <vocabulary>tattoo</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is a な adjective version of the kanji which means <kanji>calm</kanji>. The vocab version here is <vocabulary>calm</vocabulary> as well, though you can use it to mean <vocabulary>mild</vocabulary> as well.
Everything is <kanji>calm</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>proper</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reasonable</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>flat</kanji> <kanji>calm</kanji> is a <vocabulary>calm</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tranquil</vocabulary> place.

Something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>calm</kanji> is in a state of <vocabulary>unrest</vocabulary>. When things are <vocabulary>unsettled</vocabulary>, it's <vocabulary>disquieting</vocabulary> for people.

不穏 is generally used to describe the unsettling mood or atmosphere of a situation, highlighting tension and unease rather than describing something physical.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>dull</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>dull</vocabulary>.

If you’re too <kanji>dull</kanji> to have <kanji>feeling</kanji>, you’re <vocabulary>insensitive</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>thickheaded</vocabulary>.

鈍感 often means someone's not very tuned in to emotions or what's happening around them. It's like they can miss subtle romantic hints or not sense the silent tension in a room.
You're using a <kanji>dull</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> as a <vocabulary>blunt weapon</vocabulary>. It's all you have to hand.
A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>devil</kanji> is a <vocabulary>devil</vocabulary> (because they're all bad), or a <vocabulary>demon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>satan</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>devil</kanji>'s <kanji>method</kanji> is <vocabulary>magic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>witchcraft</vocabulary>. That's their method of doing things, after all.

The <kanji>devil</kanji>'s <kanji>technique</kanji> is <vocabulary>sorcery</vocabulary>. The kind of thing that devils do.

魔術 is a word that refers to <vocabulary>magic arts</vocabulary>, with emphasis on the "craft" of magic.
A <kanji>devil</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is a <vocabulary>witch</vocabulary>. She uses magic, so she must be a witch! Also, does she float like wood / a very small rock?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a <vocabulary>hostel</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>dormitory</kanji> <kanji>student</kanji> (comes from 学生) is a <vocabulary>boarding student</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>boarder</vocabulary>. This is a student who lives in a dormitory.

The kanji 盆 means <kanji>tray</kanji> or <kanji>ancestral festival</kanji>. The お just adds politeness or respect. So お盆 also means <vocabulary>tray</vocabulary>, or refers to the <vocabulary>ancestral festival</vocabulary> also known as Obon.

Usually, the context will tell you which meaning for お盆 is being used, but you can also distinguish between them by the pitch accent. お盆 for "tray" uses a Low-High-High accent (like our female audio), and お盆 for "ancestral festival" uses a Low-High-Low accent (like our male audio).
This is the same as the kanji, <vocabulary>rather</vocabulary>. Can also mean <vocabulary>better</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instead</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>street</kanji> <kanji>rather</kanji> than a not-street. That's what I'm offering you to walk on. It's much nicer this way. I am being <vocabulary>polite</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>courteous</vocabulary> by offering you this street.
A <kanji>sick</kanji> <kanji>building</kanji> is a building (or part of a building) for sick people. In other words, a <vocabulary>hospital ward</vocabulary>.

<kanji>I</kanji>, my <kanji>comrade</kanji> (which is me), is <vocabulary>I</vocabulary>, it's <vocabulary>myself</vocabulary>, it's <vocabulary>me</vocabulary>. This is a weird way to say "I" and has a hint of arrogance to it.

Something that has <kanji>slice</kanji>d <kanji>new</kanji>ness into the world is <vocabulary>novel</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>original</vocabulary>. Just imagine the world as a place of things that are already done. If you want to get something <vocabulary>innovative</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inventive</vocabulary> in there, you have to slice that oldness open to make space for the new.

斬新 is often used when you want to commend someone's creativity, novelty, or forward-thinking. However, it can also be used as a polite way of saying something is unusual or unexpectedly different, without openly calling it strange.
A <kanji>slice</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is a <vocabulary>killing with a sword</vocabulary>. You don't want to hear this, if at all possible.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>slice</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to cut down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to slice off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lop off</vocabulary>. 

This word mainly refers to cutting people with a sword, if you haven't figured it out yet.
A <kanji>chair</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is for some reason just a <vocabulary>chair</vocabulary>. Not sure why it's a child, but it is.

<kanji>Year</kanji>s and <kanji>month</kanji>s show the passage of <vocabulary>time</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>years</vocabulary> gone by.

歳月 is a relatively formal word that's often used in literature when reflecting on the passage of long periods of time — usually in a way that's poetic, thoughtful, or emotional.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on the end of numbers to show how old someone is.

You already learned 〜才 (years old), and 〜歳 means the exact same thing. No trick questions here. The difference is that 歳 is a pretty complicated kanji, so 才 is the simplified, more casual option for easier readability. Basically, 才 is the jeans-and-t-shirt version, while 歳 shows up in a suit and tie when things get official.
A <kanji>pure</kanji> <kanji>cool</kanji> is <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary>, isn't it.
A <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>wind</kanji> is a <vocabulary>cool breeze</vocabulary>.

If 真似 is <kanji>imitation</kanji> and if a <kanji>monkey</kanji> is doing said imitation, that's summed up by the saying: <vocabulary>monkey see monkey do</vocabulary>.

This refers to when someone does a <vocabulary>mindless imitation</vocabulary> of others without any real thought, so is often used when criticizing people.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Remember, this is the eyeball pupil.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Zero</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> is <vocabulary>below zero</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Sub zero</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Zero</kanji> <kanji>o'clock</kanji> is 0:00. That's <vocabulary>midnight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>twelve o'clock</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Zero</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji>s means you got <vocabulary>zero point</vocabulary>s. Could also refer to getting <vocabulary>zero marks</vocabulary> on your test.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, so this is <vocabulary>Go</vocabulary>, as in <vocabulary>the game of Go</vocabulary>.

碁 is the classic East Asian game of strategy played with black and white stones on a large grid board. It can be used on its own, but you'll also often see it in compounds such as 碁石 (ごいし) or 碁会所 (ごかいしょ).

When do you <kanji>surround</kanji> your enemy's <kanji>Go</kanji> pieces with your own? When you're playing <vocabulary>Go</vocabulary>!

碁 and 囲碁 are exactly the same thing, but 碁 sounds slightly more formal and 囲碁 is more common when talking about <vocabulary>the game of Go</vocabulary> in everyday conversations.

A <kanji>Go</kanji> <kanji>tray</kanji> is a tray for playing the game of Go. In other words, it's a <vocabulary>Go board</vocabulary>.

碁盤 refers to the gridded wooden game board where players place their Go stones and engage in tiny, polite battles.

A <kanji>Go</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing <kanji>place</kanji> is a place where people meet to play Go. It's a <vocabulary>Go parlor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Go playing parlor</vocabulary>.

碁会所 is a place where people gather to play Go, chat, and quietly judge each other's life choices based on their opening moves. There, you'll find both seasoned veterans and hopeful beginners sharing the same tables… and occasionally the same sighs of regret.

This <kanji>tariff</kanji> <kanji>world</kanji> you live in is a <vocabulary>foreign concession</vocabulary>. It's a <vocabulary>foreign settlement</vocabulary> in another country where foreigners get to make up all the rules, so they've gone and slapped tariffs on everything to annoy the country's native government.

租界 is most commonly used to refer to the foreign-controlled areas in China that had their own rules and law enforcement during the late 1800s and early 1900s. You'll mostly see it in historical contexts, but it's also sometimes used in fiction to describe foreign-controlled districts in imagined settings.
A <kanji>tariff</kanji> <kanji>tax</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>taxes</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>taxation</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Energy</kanji> <kanji>bubbles</kanji> are bubbles filled with the "energy" that's all around us (air). That's why this is an <vocabulary>air bubble</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>bubbles</kanji> are bubbles that come from the water. This is usually in the form of <vocabulary>foam</vocabulary>, but could also be a <vocabulary>bubble</vocabulary>.

水泡 is a literary word, mainly seen in the idiom 水泡に帰す (to come to nothing). This phrase paints a picture of your efforts going down the drain, turning into foam or bubbles in the water, and ultimately disappearing into nothingness.

The <kanji>departure</kanji> of <kanji>bubbles</kanji> is when bubbles leave something, like a mouth. That's why this is <vocabulary>foaming</vocabulary>.

発泡 is a technical word used for something that's filled with air bubbles or produces foam. It's often used in materials and product names, like 発泡スチロール (styrofoam), 発泡酒 (low-malt beer), or 発泡剤 (foaming agent).
The kanji itself means <kanji>habit</kanji> but it usually refers to a <vocabulary>bad habit</vocabulary>, so try to remember that meaning if you could.
<kanji>Secluded</kanji> and <kanji>closed</kanji> off, putting you in <vocabulary>confinement</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>imprisonment</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>secluded</kanji> <kanji>ghost</kanji> is someone who's secluded and a ghost, because everyone's forgotten about him (thus the "ghostness" of him). This thing is a <vocabulary>ghost</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>specter</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>mouth</kanji> <kanji>habit</kanji> is something you say with your mouth a lot. It's a habit. It's your <vocabulary>favorite phrase</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>catchphrase</vocabulary>. Many people have the <vocabulary>habit of saying</vocabulary> the certain things over and over again, whether they want to or not.

When you <kanji>forge</kanji> and <kanji>temper</kanji> yourself, you're probably <vocabulary>training</vocabulary> your body or trying to <vocabulary>discipline</vocabulary> yourself to be physically and mentally tougher.

鍛錬 once described forging metal, but now it's usually about strengthening yourself. Think about how you push yourself again and again, like a blacksmith pounding hot iron, to mold your mind, body, and abilities into something stronger!! That's 鍛錬.
<kanji>Tempering</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> is a <kanji>technique</kanji> so magical that we can consider it to be <vocabulary>alchemy</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>forge</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to forge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to temper</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>head of plant</kanji> of a <kanji>rice plant</kanji> is the <vocabulary>head of rice</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ear of rice</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>sovereign</kanji> <kanji>emperor</kanji> of Japan is also the <vocabulary>emperor</vocabulary> of other places too!

The one true <kanji>sovereign</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Japanese emperor</vocabulary>, a.k.a. the <vocabulary>emperor of Japan</vocabulary>. On its own, 帝 only refers to him, not to other emperors around the world.

帝 is a classical term for the emperor in Japan. It's found in works of classical literature, historical novels, or period dramas that are set in feudal Japan. In modern Japanese, the Japanese emperor is called 天皇.
A <kanji>sovereign</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is one that is part of its own <vocabulary>empire</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Sovereign</kanji> <kanji>government</kanji> and <kanji>Politics</kanji> are those who are part of the <vocabulary>imperial government</vocabulary>. This type of government is <vocabulary>imperialism</vocabulary>. Of course, back in the day there weren't as many sovereign governments out there, so imperialism is the one that fits the bill in this word's case.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>blink</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to blink</vocabulary>.

This word is generally used in the phrase 瞬く間に (in the blink of an eye).
A <kanji>blink</kanji> <kanji>interval of time</kanji> is a very short period of time. It's <vocabulary>an instant</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>moment</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>blink</kanji> of <kanji>time</kanji> is a mere <vocabulary>moment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>white</kanji> <kanji>chrysanthemum</kanji> is a <vocabulary>white chrysanthemum</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>pride</kanji> is too <kanji>big</kanji>. You make it bigger than it is, in fact. You do this with <vocabulary>exaggeration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hyperbole</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>blink</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blink</vocabulary> and a <vocabulary>wink</vocabulary> as well, depending on how many eyes you use.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>blink</kanji> is one instant. That is <vocabulary>an instant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a moment</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pride</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to be proud of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to boast of</vocabulary>.
Take your <kanji>pride</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it out. It's an <vocabulary>exaggeration</vocabulary>, because you've stretched your pride out pretty thin.

A <kanji>manor</kanji> with a <kanji>park</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>manor</vocabulary> — it's just a really big and impressive one.

庄園 refers to a medieval-style manor — a large <vocabulary>agricultural estate</vocabulary> granted to a lord by the monarch to be managed privately as a source of personal income. In Japan, 庄園 were an important part of the medieval economic system, with the aristocracy and the religious establishment controlling thousands of them around the country. Many famous samurai families took their names from 庄園, as they often managed them locally in place of absentee owners who preferred to hang out in Kyoto.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>thwart</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to thwart</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hamper</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>thwart</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji> something, you are an <vocabulary>obstruction</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hindrance</vocabulary>.

阻止 is a relatively formal word that means <vocabulary>preventing</vocabulary> something from happening, often by actively resisting rather than just stopping something passively.
<kanji>Thwart</kanji> and <kanji>damage</kanji> the advancement of something. That's an <vocabulary>obstruction</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inhibition</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shut up</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shut up</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>sink</kanji> down and <kanji>shut up</kanji>. You go into a <vocabulary>silence</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hush</vocabulary>. This tends to be an awkward silence or hush.
<kanji>Shut up</kanji> and <kanji>kill</kanji> your talking or I'll kill it for you. I'm not listening to this. I'm <vocabulary>ignoring</vocabulary> it.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

On the <kanji>soil</kanji> we put <kanji>straw sack</kanji>s in a circle to mark a <vocabulary>sumo ring</vocabulary>. Go look up some pictures of this word in Japanese and you'll see exactly what we mean. Better yet, go see some live sumo!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>cotton</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>cotton cloth</vocabulary> of <vocabulary>cotton material</vocabulary>.

If you have a <kanji>shelf</kanji> to <kanji>establish</kanji> on your wall, you'll need to do some <vocabulary>construction</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>installation</vocabulary> work. 

架設 is pretty formal. Use it specifically for the kind of construction or installation you do with bridges, cables, electric lines, pipelines, and other stuff that stretches like a "shelf" from one point to another.
A <kanji>write</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a shelf with writing on it. That's a <vocabulary>bookshelf</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bookcase</vocabulary>.
It will <kanji>carry</kanji> or <kanji>bear</kanji> people like a <kanji>shelf</kanji>. This thing that carries people is a <vocabulary>stretcher</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>litter</vocabulary>.

紛らわしい is "confusing" or "misleading." This is the negative of that (you can tell by the ない), meaning it's kind of the opposite of those things. This word is <vocabulary>unmistakable</vocabulary>, <vocabulary> indisputable </vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>pupil</kanji> <kanji>hole</kanji> is still your <vocabulary>pupil</vocabulary>. It can also be called your <vocabulary>pupillary</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>cavity</kanji> (hole) is where your eye is held. This is your <vocabulary>eye socket</vocabulary>.
You have a <kanji>measurement</kanji> (3.03 cm!) of <kanji>spare time</kanji>. This isn't much free time, but it's a <vocabulary>free minute</vocabulary> that you have.
The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Hey look! If you weren't sick of them yet, it's another verb that goes with <kanji>shake</kanji>! This one means <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> too!
<kanji>Cotton</kanji> that comes off a <kanji>tree</kanji> is still <vocabulary>cotton</vocabulary>!
